oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Eighth Surveyors District of Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Includes the area of south-central Tennessee below the Military Reservation from the Tennessee River on the west through present-day Perry, Hickman, and Maury counties to Columbia. Because these surveyor district maps were produced by official state surveyors to facilitate the location of public land entries and grants, they are divided into equidistant townships and sections. They also show named streams, roads, and some towns as well as, in this case, the southern boundary of the North Carolina military reservation for Revolutionary War grantees.
The twelve district surveyors maps were produced as Indian treaties and land cessions opened up new territory for state land sales--the location of which "grants" was their chief purpose.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aboriginal map of Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Composite map showing stations and settlements of East Tennessee, the North Carolina Military Reservation of 1783, the Congressional Reservation of 1808, the Western Purchase of 1818. The map's chief purpose was to indicate locations of the native towns and frontier forted stations and settlements that figured in the early history of Tennessee and Alabama territories.
Published as part of Goodspeed's General History of Tennessee (1886).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Geographical, statistical, and historical map of Tennessee (1822)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: No. 28 from Carey and Lea's Complete Historical, Chronological and Geographical American Atlas. Shows existing counties, some towns, roads, streams. West Tennessee counties are shown soon after their formation. Populations broken down by whites, free blacks, slaves and the state population in 1790, 1800 and 1810. Chief towns are listed with data.
Chief value of this map lies in depicting the state in the early 1820s following the Jackson Purchase and the cession of Chickasaw land in western Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Eleventh Surveyors District of Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This surveyor's district covered the southwest corner of the newly acquired west Tennessee--present-day Tipton, Haywood, Shelby, Fayette counties--and shows range and section lines, streams and general soil qualities ("1st rate," "2nd rate," etc.). West Tennessee had just been acquired from the Chickasaw, so there are no settlements or towns. Because these surveyor district maps were produced by official state surveyors to facilitate the location of public land entries and grants, they are divided into equidistant townships and sections.
The twelve district surveyors maps were produced as Indian treaties and land cessions opened up new territory for state land sales--the location of which "grants" was their chief purpose.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Seventh Surveyors District of Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Includes the area from the Tennessee River on the west and the Alabama state line on the south through present-day Hardin, Wayne, Lawrence and Giles counties to the meridian on the east. Shows range and section lines, streams, some roads, the town of Pulaski, and general soil qualities. Because these surveyor district maps were produced by official state surveyors to facilitate the location of public land entries and grants, they are divided into equidistant townships and sections. Again, for the benefit of prospective grantees, there are ratings of land quality.
The twelve district surveyors maps were produced as Indian treaties and land cessions opened up new territory for state land sales--the location of which "grants" was their chief purpose.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Kentucky and Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This color map features the post offices, post roads, canals, and railroads of Kentucky and Tennessee. Major cities and towns, rivers and creeks, and county lines are featured. Postal routes are displayed in the categories of mail, post, coach, stage, sulkey, crossroads, railroads, and canals.

The importance of the operations of the United States Postal Service during this time period is highlighted by the creation of such a series of postal maps. Emerging modes of transportation continued to benefit from the support of the Postal Service. As the Service strove to improve means of mail delivery from Revolutionary times onward, it embraced the development of congressionally-authorized "postal roads" as represented in this map. David H. Burr served as the official topographer for the U.S.P.S. Dept.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Burr, David H., 1803-1875

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mining districts of East Tennessee, western North Carolina, and north Georgia (1833)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This geological and topographical map details where gold, zinc, coal, lead and other mineral resources could be found in East Tennessee, western parts of North Carolina and areas of North Georgia. The map includes a picture of a smelting pot, a view of the mountains and the Tennessee River, and a chart indicating the height of the mountains. The perimeter of the map contains copious notes written by Jack Peck and John Barber. Towns, counties, and other place names are also indicated on the map.

This map appeared in the American Journal of Science and Arts, Vol. 23, 1833. The map was addressed to the Hon. Judge Jacob Peck of New Market, Tennessee. It contains various hand-written notes about the map, both to Peck (from John M. Barber) as well as; notes from Peck himself. The Cherokees were occupying much of this land at this point, but the discovery of gold would eventually lead to their removal.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Peck, Jacob, 1779-1869

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the British American Plantations (1754)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "A map of the British American plantations, extending from Boston in New England to Georgia; including all the back settlements in the respective provinces as far as the Mississippi." An exceptional map of the American colonies and backcountry published in London at the time of the French & Indian War. It shows the territory of the "Cherakees," "Chikasas," and Upper Creeks with their towns and villages, including the site of "Tanase" from which the future state's name derived. Walker's Settlement 1750, the site of what would later be called the Muscle Shoals, and an "English Fort"--probably Fort Loudoun--indicated. Possibly the earliest map of the Tennessee country at TSLA.
Emanuel Bowen was "Geographer to His Majesty" [George II].

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the State of Tennessee taken from survey by Matthew Rhea (1832)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is the best overall map of Tennessee in the early national period. It shows counties, stage roads, Indian boundary lines, old forts, Indian villages, mills, iron works as well as streams, settlements, ranges and sections in West Tennessee, a geological cross-section of the state, a chronological statement of Tennessee history, a statistical table on counties showing dates established, and the total population and principal exports of counties. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Military map showing the theater of operations in the Tullahoma, Chickamauga and Chattanooga campaigns
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This Civil War map showing the theater of Tennessee operations during General William Rosecrans 1863 Tullahoma and Chattanooga campaigns against general Braxton Bragg's Army of Tennessee. Prepared after the war under the direction of the Honorable Daniel S. Lamont, Secretary of War, by the Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Park Commission and based on wartime mapping of the important Federal mapmaker Col. William E. Merrill, U. S. Topographical Engineers.

The Tullahoma, Chickamauga, and Chattanooga Campaigns were significant military operations in Tennessee during 1863. Merrill served under William T. Sherman and provided maps for the campaign from Chattanooga to Atlanta.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee (1822)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Beautiful color map of Tennessee as it appeared in 1822, soon after the cession by treaty of Chickasaw lands between the Tennessee and Mississippi Rivers. The map shows the newly formed West Tennessee counties in different colors and short-lived configurations that would change as new counties were formed. It also shows county seats, rivers, and mountains. Recently formed (by the New Madrid earthquakes of 1812-13) Reelfoot Lake appears as a rather fanciful "Wood Lake;" Muscle Shoals in Alabama can also be seen, in addition to some Cherokee lands in southeast Tennessee.
Newly created counties in West Tennessee are shown. After the treaty with the Chickasaws in 1818, new land was added to the western region of Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lucas, Fielding, Jr., 1781-1854

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Includes Maryland, Virginia, Kentucky, Territory South of the Ohio, North Carolina, Tennessee Government, South Carolina and Georgia.This map shows the southern states of the United States, and includes rivers, mountains, towns, bays, donation lands from the Commonwealth of Virginia Company, various speculative land companies such as the Wabash Company, the New Jersey Company, the Ohio Company, and army lands. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Appleton's railway map of the United States and the Canadas
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map illustrates the Civil War-era railroad routes of the United States and Canada that were operating or being built around 1864. Lines are named, and major stops along each railway line are shown. An inset in the lower right corner features the area covered by the Pacific Railroad and the Gold Regions.

Compiled by G.F. Thomas. Thomas served as editor of "Appletons' Illustrated Railway Guide." This map conveys the full impact of the surge of railroad building that took hold in the 1850s across the nation. Tentative forays in the 1820s and 1830s would give way to great railway systems that would improve transportation, aid the growth of the national economy, and play a key role in the Civil War.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Thomas, G. F.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ashport to Memphis Confederate map
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map showing Confederate military installations along the Tennessee portion of the Mississippi River was hand-drawn on linen by Albert Martin around 1861. It stretches from Ashport in the north to Memphis in the south and shows Confederate artillery batteries, with number, size and type of guns. Though detailed in its presentation of waterways, swamps, bluffs, plantations, certain landowners, and the numbered islands in the Mississippi River, its primary purpose was to depict the Confederate gun emplacements--Forts Harris, Randolph and Claiborn [sic: should be Cleburne for Col. Patrick R. Cleburne whose 1st Arkansas Regt. built the earthworks, later in the war called Fort Pillow]--protecting the river above Memphis early in the war. Troop deployments in the area are also indicated.

The importance of controlling this stretch of the Mississippi River was paramount for both sides during the Civil War, but especially for the Confederacy, which the great river divided. As indicated by this map, the Southern command had fortified the bluffs above Memphis with an array of heavy gun emplacements to guard against a potential Federal riverborne assault. Note the written comment that cotton bales and barricades were present in the streets of Memphis. Memphis would cease to function as a Confederate stronghold when it fell to Union forces on June 6, 1862.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Martin, Albert
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Shelby County (Tenn.); Tipton County (Tenn.); Lauderdale County (Tenn.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map showing the lands assigned to emigrant Indians west of Arkansas and Missouri (1836)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This Congressionally authorized map shows lands designated by tribe for Indians who had emigrated and re-located west of the Mississippi River prior to the general removal of the Southeastern tribes in 1838. Indian nation boundaries in this trans-Mississippi Indian territory are named and delineated in color. Some of the emigrating Indian nations include Cherokees, Creeks, Choctaws, and Pottawatomies. Major rivers and the locations of some U.S. forts are also indicated. Included with the map are statistical charts that specify the quantity of land assigned to tribes who emigrated from the Eastern to the Western side of the Mississippi.

More data about this map can be found in the Congressional record from 1835-1836, from the House Executive Documents, Serial Number 289, Volume 4, House Document 181, from the 1st session of the 24th Congress. These documents describe Colonel Henry Dodge's expedition to the Rocky Mountains. There is detailed information about the journey, including transcriptions of speeches to Native American chiefs and tribes, and day-to-day information about their route and experiences.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jones, R., Adjutant-General

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Route of the Memphis-Nashville-Bristol highway (1911)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map showing the proposed route of the Memphis-Nashville-Bristol Highway to be constructed 1911-1913. The map shows all the counties of Tennessee with their county seats, as well as the major railroads through Tennessee. There are advertisements bordering the map that show photographs of various road-building equipment. On the reverse is an open letter from the Wilson, Ingram and Company addressed to Mr. Good Road Builder, State of Tennessee, suggesting that Austin-Western Road Machinery be used.

The construction of the Memphis to Bristol Highway offered citizens, businesses, and tourists a means to effectively cross the state and offered the opportunity to unify more closely the three grand divisions. The good roads improvement movement had arisen in the 1890s with the support of the railroads, the farm alliances, and the bicyclists, and it had widespread public approval across the state. When motorized vehicles came onto the scene at the turn of the 19th century, they provided travel competition to railroads and steamboats and spawned the creation of local auto clubs and the Tennessee Good Roads Association. The Association threw its support behind the construction of an all-weather Memphis to Bristol highway. The building of the Memphis to Bristol Highway encouraged the undertaking of additional state road-building projects and encouraged Virginia and Mississippi to extend the highway. Local businessmen had formed the Memphis to Bristol Highway Association in 1911 to promote this 500-mile long highway. In 1926, two-thirds of the route was designated as U. S. 70, the major east-west corridor in the region. In the late 1920s the entire route became part of the Broadway of America Highway from California to New York.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the First Surveyors District of Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map showing range and section lines, counties, streams, some roads, and county seats of Tennessee's First Surveyors District--basically the old North Carolina Military Reservation of middle Tennessee. The Tennessee River appears at the western edge of the map. The counties of Montgomery, Robertson, Sumner, Dickson, Davidson, Williamson, Rutherford, Wilson, Smith, Jackson, and White are labeled. The country seats that are designated are Clarksville, Springfield, Gallatin, Charlotte, Nashville, Franklin, Jefferson, Lebanon, Carthage, and Williamsburg. Because these surveyor district maps were produced by official state surveyors to facilitate the location of public land entries and grants, they are divided into equidistant townships and sections. This especially large map has been divided into six images.
The twelve district surveyors maps were produced as Indian treaties and land cessions opened up new territory for state land sales--the location of which "grants" was their chief purpose.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Benjamin F. Cheatham Civil War map of Nashville and surrounding counties
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Military map of Middle Tennessee from the Benjamin Franklin Cheatham Papers, showing cities and towns, roads, turnpikes, toll roads, railroads, rivers and streams in Bedford, Cannon, Cheatham, Davidson, Maury, Robertson, Rutherford, Sumner, Trousdale, Williamson, and Wilson counties. As a division and, later, corps commander in the Confederate Army of Tennessee, Cheatham may have used this detailed map for operations in Middle Tennessee.

Benjamin Franklin Cheatham (1820-1886) was a major general and corps commander in the Confederate Army of Tennessee during the Civil War. There is a notation on this map indicating it was copied from a Federal map.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nashville and the camp of the sixteenth regiment of Ills. Vols. Inft. at Edgefield, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A pictorial lithograph of Nashville and Edgefield during the Civil War, with the camp of the Illinois 16th Volunteer Infantry Regiment at Edgefield in the foreground. The Cumberland River is seen in the background with gunboats and riverboats depicted. The state capitol building can be seen in the background overlooking the city of Nashville. Structures featured within the camp are the guard house, the headquarters, the hospital, the sutler, a medical procedure, African American laborers, and the housing for the band.

The lithograph depicts camp activities as might be seen during the Civil War. The lithograph was created by Theodore Schrader of St. Louis, Missouri. The 16th Regiment Illinois Infantry was organized at Quincy, Illinois, and mustered in May 24, 1861. They marched from Tuscumbia, Alabama to Nashville from August 25 through September 15, 1862. They saw action at Columbia on September 10, 1862.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schrader, Theodore, 1812-1897

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hardeman County, Tennessee (1923)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A Tennessee Board of Natural Resources map of Hardeman County based on surveys by C. R. Watkins, Jr. in 1916 and C. C. Anderson and R. Perrin in 1921. Shows towns, roads, railroads, streams, drainage canals, residences, churches, schools, and cemeteries. This extremely detailed map shows every house structure and significant economic and demographic feature in Hardeman County.
The 1920s county maps by the state Division of Geology or, in this case, the Board of Natural Resources, are most revealing of the community and historical geography of Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of Dickson County (Tenn.) based on the Tennessee Geological Survey of 1922 by J. A. Kerr, H. G. Lewis, W. J. Latimer and E. H. Bailey of the Bureau of Soils. The Tennessee Division of Geology maps from the 1920s are among the best for historical and demographic detail.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Tennessee (1818)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This beautifully colored map of Tennessee constructed by John Melish from the surveys of John Strothers following the War of 1812. Shows early county lines and Indian boundaries prior to Jackson's Treaty and other cessions of Indian land after the war, along with some statistical and geological remarks. Western Tennessee is still Chickasaw territory, and the southeastern corner of the state is in Cherokee hands. Melish clearly was working remotely and had not been to Tennessee, as there are several fanciful mistakes such as the eastern tip of the state, the location of Reynoldsburg and the "Earthquake [Reelfoot] Lake," and numerous misspellings. Certain period features such as Fort Deposit, Southwest Point garrison, and the U.S. Agency for Cherokees are indicated.

John Melish was a Scottish-born cartographer who settled in the United States in 1811, after several previous visits. Melish came to dominate the map-making industry in this country and had a huge impact on the cartographic standards of his day.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A map of the Tennessee (note the spelling of Tennassee) government, formerly part of North Carolina taken chiefly from surveys by Genel. D[aniel] Smith and others for the American Edition of Guthrie's Geographical. This map accompanied a published guide for emigrants to the Tennessee country, shortly to become a state. Daniel Smith was a land speculator and the first secretary of state for Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This extremely detailed map shows every house structure and significant economic and demographic feature in Humphreys County. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Battle of Nashville from John Johnston's Civil War Reminiscences
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn map by Confederate cavalryman John Johnston, in two parts, detailing mostly second day (Dec. 16, 1864) events in the Battle of Nashville. First map details action on the Confederate left flank west of the city, showing the Federals attacking a small brigade of Confederate infantry near Charlotte and Harding Pikes and the line of Confederate retreat. Second map details second day and subsequent action between Nashville and Franklin of the Federal Cavalry, the retreat of Hood's Army, the scene of General Rucker's capture, and the last stand of the 14th Regiment, all of which took place near the old Johnston homeplace.

John Johnston was born in 1842 and joined the Confederate army in April 1861. He served in Nathan Bedford Forrest's cavalry during the war. Following the war he became a lawyer in Memphis and wrote a memoir of his experiences during the Civil War. He died in 1928.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civil War map of Middle and East Tennessee and parts of Alabama and Georgia
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Union army operational map of Middle and East Tennessee as far west as Savannah, as far east as Knoxville, as far North as Clarksville, and south into Georgia and Alabama. Displays roads and their names, numerous cities (Nashville, Perryville, Kingston, Chattanooga, et al), major rivers (Tennessee, Cumberland, Duck, Hiwassee, Clinch, Holston, et al). "Middle Tennessee etc. No. 39" is written on the back, as is the name Major Michler, Eng., the map's creator. Map shows the prospective route of the military Nashville & Northwestern Railroad from Nashville west to the Tennessee River, as well as numerous wartime details such as the Pinewood factory, ferries and old iron furnaces. The cotton label from the map backing is also still present.

Produced by U. S. topographical engineers under the direction of Nathaniel Michler, who headed the Topographical Department in the Army of the Potomac. "General Rosencrans" is also written on the back of the map. Rosencrans was commander of the Army of the Cumberland, one of the armies for which the map was specifically produced.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Michler, N. (Nathaniel), 1827-1881; Weyss, J. E.; Mercell, C. S.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civil War map of the Seat of War
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of the major locations of the Civil War in 1863 showing the states of Ohio, Maryland, Missouri, Arkansas, Louisiana, Kentucky, Tennessee, Mississippi, Alabama, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Florida. Shows major waterways, main railroad lines, strategic points, and military lines of communication. The original map is mounted in a fragile book and had to be scanned in four sections.

The map was prepared by "a Confederate officer at the commencement of the war" and later became the property of General Nathaniel P. Banks. It was published by E. Ezekiel of the Exchange bookstore in New Orleans, Louisiana and dedicated by its author, Confederate engineer W. H. Wilder, to the Confederate Sec. of War L. Pope Walker.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Battlefield in front of Franklin, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Published by the authority of the Secretary of War in the Office of the Chief Engineers, U.S. Army, 1874. Map shows Battle of Franklin where the United States Forces repulsed the Confederate Army on November 30, 1864. Includes topography, roads, disposition of Union works and Confederate forces, houses and landowners, fortified positions, and layout of Town of Franklin.

Though published ten years after the battle, this map contains a wealth of important details and was compiled by Col. William E. Merrill, one of the foremost Union cartographers working in Tennessee during the Civil War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civil War map of the country between Franklin and Columbia
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand drawn map, dated May 1863 and made under the direction of Union cartographer Capt. William Merrill, of the country between Franklin and Columbia featuring the positions of roads, railroads, and the Duck River. Very detailed map also provides the names of towns, tollgates, ferries and the owners of individual property. The map depicts the exact terrain over which Gen. Hood's Army of Tennessee moved from November 28-30, 1864 in its maneuvering against Gen. Schofield's Federal army at Spring Hill and Franklin. It was made from Capt. Dunham's Survey and information collected by cartographic engineer Thomas Sedgwick.

The map was produced under the direction of Federal mapmaker William E. Merrill, U. S. Engineers. Merrill served under William T. Sherman and provided maps of middle Tennessee and for the campaign from Chattanooga to Atlanta.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civil War map of Knoxville and surrounding area showing fortifications and other landmarks
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn map showing the area around Knoxville, indicating Fort Sanders and other Union fortifications and regiments at the time of the Confederate assault on the city in November 1863. The map was created by Union soldier Seth Alden Abbey (1798-1880) and was included in a diary that he kept. The map shows the disposition of forces, barracks, hilltop gun emplacements, Confederate lines and "Rebel ferry" involved in the Battle of Knoxville.

Seth Abbey came to Cleveland in 1830 with his widowed father, Peter Abbey, from Enfield, Connecticut. Seth Abbey assisted in the incorporation of the city in 1836 by serving, along with Edmund Clark and Richard Winslow, as judge of elections. He was also city marshal for a time, as well as judge of police court. When the Civil War broke out, he enlisted and served in the Ohio Volunteer Cavalry.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civil War map of Virginia showing area around Richmond, Petersburg and Williamsburg
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map showing Tidewater Virginia on the lower York and James River peninsulas during the Civil War, with detailed depiction of roads, bridges, encampments, forts, railroads, courthouses and towns. The map was created by Ohio Union cavalryman Seth Alden Abbey (1798-1880) and was included in a diary that he kept.

Seth Abbey came to Cleveland in 1830 with his widowed father, Peter Abbey, from Enfield, Connecticut. Seth Abbey assisted in the incorporation of the city in 1836 by serving, along with Edmund Clark and Richard Winslow, as judge of elections. He was also city marshal for a time, as well as judge of police court. When the Civil War broke out, he enlisted and served in the Ohio Volunteer Cavalry.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mid-twentieth century map of the Battle of Franklin, based on original sources, featuring Union and Confederate troop positions, a diagram of the town of Franklin, Union breastworks and other fortifications. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Dover, Tennessee and the [Fort Donelson] Battlefield
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn map, done by an Illinois soldier who was present, of the Battle for Fort Donelson showing location of artillery placements, Union breastworks, Confederate rifle pits, the guard house, Dover churches and town buildings (including the Dover hotel where Confederate forces were surrendered), and major roads and streams.

On February 16, 1862, the Federal Army in Tennessee, under the command of Brigadier General Ulysses S. Grant, won its first major victory of the Civil War, capturing Fort Donelson. The defeat opened a pathway to Nashville, which fell quickly into Union hands, giving the Union Army a foothold in the deep South.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Franklin, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn Civil War map of Franklin, done by a Confederate soldier, showing locations of Fort Grainger, Union and Confederate positions at the November 30, 1864 battle, major streams, fords, bridges, roads, and the railroad. The map includes a legend for certain places and a chronology of action of both Federal and Confederate troops near Franklin from March 1862 to December 1864.
James Marsh Morey was a corporal in Company D of the 32nd Regiment of the Tennessee Infantry organized at Franklin in Williamson County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civil War map of the area west of the Tennessee River and Chattanooga
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn pencil map done by Union army engineer Francis Mohrhardt of railroads, roads, rivers, and topological features in the area west of the Tennessee River and Chattanooga. These two leaves showing the area around Bridgeport and Stevenson, Alabama are part of a larger series of 30+ maps in which Mohrhardt shows the entire march of Gen. Rosecrans' Union Army of the Cumberland from Murfreesboro to Chattanooga during the summer of 1863, otherwise known as the Tullahoma Campaign. This operational map is very detailed as to topography and the condition of roads, fords and ferries, shows specific features such as the University at Sewanee, and includes a legend that details the specific distances between each town and city on the map.

Francis Mohrhardt was an army engineer in the Tullahoma (Tennessee) Campaign during the U. S. Civil War. He served as a topographical engineer attached to the staff of General P. H. Sherman (1862-1863).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sketch of Battle of Franklin battlefield from John Johnston's Civil War Reminiscences
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rough sketch from John Johnston's Civil War Reminiscences of the battlefield for the Battle of Franklin, November 30, 1864, showing the Franklin-Columbia Pike, Federal "entrenchment," Hood's and Cheatham's headquarters, Confederate line of battle, and topographic features.

John Johnston was born in 1842 and joined the Confederate army in April 1861. He served in Nathan Bedford Forrest's cavalry during the war. Following the war he became a lawyer in Memphis and wrote a memoir of his experiences during the Civil War. He died in 1928.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of cavalry skirmish following the Battle of Nashville from John Johnston's Civil War Reminiscences
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn map of delaying action fought by Gen. Nathan B. Forrest's cavalry, in which John Johnston served, on December 17, 1864. Johnston's map crudely shows the terrain on which Forrest's cavalry made a stand on the north side of the West Fork of the Harpeth River against Union infantry pursuing remnants of Hood's Army of Tennessee. Confederate forces had been routed the day before in front of Nashville, and Forrest's stand helped some of them to escape to the south. Features include the positioning of Union infantry line near Winstead Hill, the "scene of our rally" at the Harpeth, and "my route" to the Gin House.

John Johnston was born in 1842 and joined the Confederate army in April 1861. He later served in Nathan Bedford Forrest's cavalry during the war. Following the war he became a lawyer in Memphis and wrote a memoir of his experiences during the Civil War. He died in 1928.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Battle of Nashville from John Johnston's Civil War Reminiscences
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn map by Confederate cavalryman John Johnston of actions south of the city during the Dec. 15-16, 1864 Battle of Nashville (mostly first day). It shows the positions of Rucker's Brigade (part of Forrest's cavalry to which Johnston was attached), Union picket lines, Confederate Gen. Hood's line, General Hatch's Union Cavalry, and the lines of probable Confederate retreat. The map also shows the Cumberland River and Charlotte, Harding, Hillsboro, Granny White, Franklin, and Murfreesboro Pikes.

John Johnston was born in 1842 and joined the Confederate army in April 1861. He served in Nathan Bedford Forrest's cavalry during the war. Following the war he became a lawyer in Memphis and wrote a memoir of his experiences during the Civil War, for which these maps were drawn. He died in 1928.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lloyd's official map of the State of Tennessee (1863)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map depicting major features, especially roads, communities and railroads, present in Tennessee during the Civil War. A large detailed section of Kentucky occupies the top part of the map, and the states surrounding Tennessee receive fringe coverage. Counties are indicated in color, and major battle sites in Tennessee are underlined in red.

There are various editions of this map, but it was initially designed as a companion map to Lloyd's official map of the State of Kentucky. Being issued from the same plate, this does explain the appearance of almost all of Kentucky on this Tennessee map. James T. Lloyd and Company of New York and London was a popular map publisher of the day, often incorporating advertisements and testimonials. Lloyd even contended his maps had been used for military planning; thus, they were "official."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lloyd, James T.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stones River Battlefield topographical map
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: After-the-fact, hand-drawn map of the Battle of Stones River (Dec. 30, 1862-Jan. 2, 1863) displays the positions of Federal and Confederate divisions and the names of their commanders. The map also features the locations of wooded areas, landowners, commander's headquarters, rivers, roads, and railroads, and the layout of Murfreesboro. Probably done in preparation for the dedication of a national military cemetery or military park.

The map was produced by U. S. topographical engineers who produced several other maps of the Battle of Stones River under the direction of Nathaniel Michler, who headed the Topographical Department in the Army of the Potomac. The name "L. M. Radford, surveyor, National Cemetery" also appears on the map. Faded writing on the back suggests it was presented to the Tennessee Historical Society but provides no date.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of East Tennessee, North of Loudon (1864)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This very fine Civil War map of East Tennessee was prepared by Union Army engineer and cartographer Orlando M. Poe. State geologist James M. Stafford drew on topographical details. This map shows forts, towns, post offices, topography, roads, railroads, valleys, rivers, creeks, islands, fords, ferries, elevations, iron furnaces, poor houses, mills and forges in the East Tennessee area. It carries the signature of W. L. B. Jenney, Captain, U.S.A.

Civil War cartographers were involved in reconnaissance, pre-battle, and post-battle mapping. Orlando Poe functioned as Chief Engineer of the XXIII Corps, and his work aided in the capture of Knoxville, Tennessee by Federal forces. After this action, he was selected by Major General W. T. Sherman as chief engineer for his Military Division of the Mississippi in the spring of 1864. Poe served Sherman during the burning of Atlanta, Sherman's March to the Sea, and the Carolinas Campaign.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Denmark, Tennessee, from John Johnston's Civil War Reminiscences
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn map of the town of Denmark, Tennessee, John Johnston's hometown, displaying the number-coded locations of homes, farms, roads, railroads, the town store, post office, and cemetery. The map depicts the town as it would have appeared at the time of the Battle of Britton Lane in Sept. 1862, when Forrest sent 87 captured Federal cavalrymen to the Presbyterian church/Masonic lodge in Denmark. It also displays the location of hills, Big Black Creek, and other topographical features.

John Johnston was born in 1842 and joined the Confederate army in April 1861. He served in Nathan Bedford Forrest's cavalry during the war. Following the war he became a lawyer in Memphis and wrote a memoir of his experiences during the Civil War. He died in 1928.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civil War map of the country traversed by the Nashville and Northwestern Railroad and the Nashville, Decatur and Stevenson Railroad
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Operational map drawn by Union topographical engineer Lt. Col. H. C. Wharton showing landowner's names, detailed road system, topography, mills, with notes as to land and road quality. Map covers a portion of Middle Tennessee west of Nashville covered by the Nashville and Northwestern Railroad, and south of Nashville following the Nashville, Decatur and Stevenson Railroad and the Duck River from Columbia to its mouth. Issued by command of Major General George H. Thomas. The map basically stretches from Nashville south to Columbia and west to the Tennessee River. The new Federal depot and supply installation at Johnsonville is shown. Scale is one half inch equals a mile. Color present along some railroad and water routes.

Wharton was a graduate of West Point who served with the U. S. Engineers as Chief Topographical Engineer in the Department of the Cumberland. Such detailed engineer's maps conveyed vital information to Federal troops entering an unfamiliar area, such as inhabitants' names, locations of mills, iron furnaces, blacksmith shops, and notations of good and bad roads and fords.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Military map showing the marches of the U.S. Forces under the command of Major General W.T. Sherman
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Detailed Civil War map of the Southeastern United States featuring the marches of General William T. Sherman during his campaigns from 1863-1865. Red lines indicate the routes taken by Sherman's corps from Knoxville to Chattanooga to Decatur, Ala. through north Georgia to Atlanta, then on to Savannah and the March to the Sea and finally up to Columbia, SC.
Map was compiled under the orders of Major General W. T. Sherman at Head Quarters Military Division of the Mississippi under the direction of Brevet Major W. L. B. Jenney, Captain Aide-de-camp U.S.A.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This detailed operational map belonged to Gen. Cheatham and shows the area around Atlanta, Ga. and to the northeast traversed by the Confederate Army of Tennessee in the spring and summer of 1864. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Davidson County, Tennessee showing rural delivery service
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map of Davidson County (Tenn.) showing rural free delivery (RFD) routes, dwellings, schools and churches. These blue-line rural free delivery (RFD) county postal maps are extremely detailed and contain much valuable early 20th century genealogical and historical data.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee (1796)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A color annotated map of Tennessee in 1796 taken from Mathew Carey's General Atlas. This topographical map shows the new state as two non-contiguous parts: the Mero District (Tennessee, Davidson and Sumner counties) and the Washington District (Sullivan, Greene, Washington, Hawkins, Knox, Jefferson and Blount counties) separated by Cherokee lands.
Depicts Tennessee as it was at the time of statehood in 1796.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Carte de la Partie de la Virginie ou l'Armee Combinee de France & des Etats-Unis de l'Amerique
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand colored French map showing the successful siege of Lord Cornwallis' army at Yorktown on Oct. 19, 1781 by united French and American armies under the command of Comte de Rochambeau and Gen. George Washington, respectively. This beautiful 18th century map, published in Paris soon after the events, also depicts the naval phase of the Yorktown campaign whereby a French fleet under Admiral de Grasse blockaded Chesapeake Bay and prevented a British fleet from rescuing Cornwallis' army.

The Battle of Yorktown was the decisive victory by French and Continental Army troops and Virginia militia over Lord Cornwallis and his British and Tory forces that effectively ended the American Revolutionary War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hand-drawn 1862 map of West Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn map of West Tennessee executed by B. J. Radford, cartographer with 3rd Brigade, 1st Division, 18th (?) Illinois Volunteers, commanded by Col. L. F. Ross. Notation on back that map had been shown to Carl Sandburg.; Official Records, Series 1, Vol. 10, Part 1, p. 140. Drawn at Bolivar, Tenn., August 1862. Shows the area between the Tennessee and Mississippi Rivers. It sites Pittsburg Landing, Britten's Lane, Island No. 10, and Grand Junction.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of "The Heights of Dover"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn map of Dover and disposition of forces at Fort Donelson, contained in an album written by Lt. Col. Milton A. Haynes, of McCown's Artillery. Haynes was the executive officer of the Artillery Corps of Tennessee. The map, titled "Battle of the Heights of Dover" contains the locations of Pillow's Division, Buckner's Division, and the Cumberland River.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Blount County (1834)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn map of Blount County (Tenn.) that shows the French Broad River, Chilhowee Mountain, Tuckaleechee Cove, Cades Cove, Cherokee villages of Tallassee and Tellico and Callaway's Turnpike connecting them, and the North Carolina border. This map was either drawn by or sent to Matthew Rhea, probably for use by him in his seminal 1834 map of the State of Tennessee.
Matthew Rhea was a cartographer, geologist and educator from Tennessee who made many contributions to the intellectual and cultural life of Tennessee.

Evans' hand drawn and colored map of Claiborne County (Tenn.) showing details of road and towns, the Crockett Ironworks and Furnace, the Kentucky Road coming from Cumberland Gap, the Clinch River, Powell River and Kentucky border. Evans addresses this map to Matthew Rhea, probably for use by the latter in his seminal 1834 map of the State of Tennessee.
Matthew Rhea was a cartographer, geologist and educator from Tennessee who made many contributions to the intellectual and cultural life of Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of downtown Chattanooga saloon district (1911)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A color-coded map made as an exhibit for an East Tennessee Supreme Court case (ET 1185). Shows properties, "business houses" and saloons owned by defendant Irene Friedman and other groups (including "property occupied by Negros") in the "red light district" of Chattanooga. Shows Read House, nearby black businesses, Fire Hall No. 1, and area from 8th to 11th Streets and Carter and Chestnut Streets. From Hamilton County Chancery Court case of M. G. Weidener, et.al. vs. Irene Friedman, et.al. in 1911.

Exhibit A from East Tennessee Supreme Court case M. G. Weidner, et al, v. Irene Friedman, et al, Oct. 14, 1911. Originally part of James McMahon's deposition in which he describes how over the years Helen St. has become the start of the "red light district."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Reelfoot Lake and land grants in Lake and Obion Counties
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of Reelfoot Lake (outlined in blue) surveyed by and under the direction of W. W. Cochran from 1902-1905. This map was created as an exhibit for a court case and shows land grants and property owners' names, streams, Reelfoot Lake and the Obion County line.

The court case and map were created shortly before the land development disputes around Reelfoot Lake in 1908, which led to the murder of an attorney and famous nightrider resistance by local landowners.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Geological map of Davidson, Williamson and Maury Counties (1843)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawn by Gerard Troost, Tennessee's first State Geologist, this geological map of three Tennessee counties (Davidson, Williamson, and Maury) shows main waterways, county seats and towns, main roads, geographical identifications, and transversal sections of the land. Williamson County is outlined in red, while Maury and Davidson Counties are outlined in blue. The map appears to be hand-colored. Certain features such as the penitentiary, cedar glades and ""mastodon caves"" are shown.

This map was printed in the Seventh Report (to the Tennessee General Assembly) of Dr. G. Troost, State Geologist. Troost, a native of Holland, was Tennessee's first state geologist. He was a professor of chemistry, geology, and mineralogy at the University of Nashville for 22 years. For more information on Troost, consult the article in the Peabody Journal of Education 30, no. 5 (March 1953) by Ellen V. Piers, called "Girard Troost, Pioneer Scientist," pages 265-274.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the lands in Mississippi ceded by the Chickasaws to the United States in 1832 and 1834
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map from the survey of Henry M. Lusher shows northern half of Mississippi and adjacent parts of Alabama, Tennessee and Arkansas. The boundary line between the Chickasaw and Choctaw nations is shown beginning at the Mississippi River. Map also shows Indian settlements, white settlements, river landings, roads and trails as well as changes made to the Tennessee-Mississippi state boundary.

In 1818 the Chickasaws gave up their claims to what is now West Tennessee and western Kentucky. In the early 1830s, the Chickasaws ceded over 6,000,000 acres of land in Mississippi in exchange for lands west of the Mississippi River. John Coffee, former general of the Tennessee volunteers during the War of 1812, represented the United States in many of the treaty negotiations with the Southeastern Tribes.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Battle on Little [Big]Horn, June 25, 1876
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sketch of the Battle of Little Bighorn, which took place on June 25, 1876 in eastern Montana Territory and at which the 7th US Cavalry command under Gen. George Armstrong Custer was nearly wiped out by a large force of Sioux and Cheyenne warriors. This map shows topography and the Indian village, the road between Forts Custer and McKinnie, skirmish sites, and routes taken by detachments under Custer, Maj. Reno, and Capts. Benteen and Keogh. The map is drawn, apparently by someone who was present at the battle or who had close knowledge of it, on linen and belonged to Army officer George Buell.

This map came from the collection of Gen. George Buell, a US Army topographical engineer who was assigned to the trans-Mississippi West after the Civil War and participated in the Indian wars against the Great Plains tribes.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Ocoee District (1837)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of the Ocoee District to elucidate the 4th report of G[erard] Troost, Geologist of the State of Tennessee. The Ocoee District lay in extreme southeastern corner of Tennessee and was the last part of Indian (Cherokee) territory to be conveyed to the the state in approximately 1836. Shows Cherokee villages such as Tallassee, Crowtown and Nautlee Town as well as the white settlements of Dallas, Calhoun and Dutchtown (Ducktown). Includes an inset of an east-west cross section of the district with a key showing the rock composition, mountains and streams.
Dr. Gerald Troost (1776-1850) was an American-Dutch naturalist and mineralogist who served as State Geologist of Tennessee from 1831-1850.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A draught of the Cherokee Country: on the west side of the Twenty Four Mountains, commonly called Over the Hills
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A map drawn by British Army Lt. Henry Timberlake in 1762 that identifies the Cherokee villages on the Little Tennessee River and includes a list of the number of warriors available from each village.

British Lt. Henry Timberlake traveled to the Overhill Cherokee villages on the Little Tennessee river in late 1761 to explain the treaty signed at Fort Loudon to the Cherokees located there. He remained with the Cherokee until March 1762, keeping a journal that was published in 1765 and contains a detailed account of Cherokee life as well as this map. He later accompanied several Cherokee headmen, including Attakullakulla, the Little Carpenter, to London to meet with King George.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: City of Nashville and Edgefield (1860)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 1860 Haydon & Booth map shows public buildings, banks, stone or brick buildings, wood buildings, railroads, ward boundaries, and ward numbers. Indexes churches, houses of industry, offices of daily newspapers, donors of property to the city, free schools, banks, hotels, and foundries. Border includes nineteen pictures of prominent buildings and views: City of Nashville, Douglass Hall, View on N. Side Public Square, Hick's Block, Nashville University, and Western Military Institute, The Spring Street Baptist Church, Church of the Holy Trinity, Residence of J.B. Hayes, Esq. Near Nashville, Residence of Mrs. J.K. Polk, State Capitol, Residence of John D. Ewing, Esq., Boyd's Addition, The Howard School, Residence of Gen. Barrow, Edgefield, The Church of the Advent, Masonic Hall, Ensley Block, View N. Side Square, Inn Block, and Residence of Col. Acklen Near Nashville.

Drawn just before the Civil War, the Haydon & Booth map of Nashville is one of the most detailed and informative depictions of the antebellum city (plus the Edgefield community). In addition to a street map, it provides a 2-dimensional rendering of the footprint of each house and structure, block-by-city block. It also names civic and private buildings, landowners, and significant natural features such as streams and springs.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Second Infantry Brigade, Tennessee State Guard map of Middle Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map depicting the Middle Tennessee area of operation for the Second Infantry Brigade of the Tennessee State Guard. Featured on the map are cities and towns, major highways, parks, rivers, dams, and bridges. The brigade headquarters in Nashville is marked by a flag.

The Second Infantry Brigade was formed by a May 1942 reorganization of the Tennessee State Guard. It was commanded by Brig. Gen. Jacob McGavock Dickinson and headquartered in Nashville. The Brigade was composed of the Second Regiment, headquartered in Nashville, the Seventh Regiment, headquartered in Cookeville, and the Tenth Regiment, headquartered in Pulaski. This map was probably produced to assist in the staging of State Guard maneuvers and exercises.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Major Francis Mohrhardt's maps (and diary) of the Tullahoma Campaign (1863)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Field notes and hand-drawn pencil maps of Francis Mohrhardt, a Union major and topographical engineer in Gen. William Rosecrans' Army of the Cumberland, attached to the staff of Gen. Philip Sheridan, include numerous pencil-drawn maps of this army's 1863 summer campaign from Murfreesboro to Chattanooga, Tenn., otherwise known as the Tullahoma Campaign. A large series of 30+ maps, which show in detail the road taken by the army from its encampment near Murfreesboro to its crossing of the Tennessee River near Bridgeport, Alabama and its eventual arrival in Chattanooga. Different plates depict the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad line, bridges and ferries, forts and breastworks, homes and structures along the road, Tullahoma, the University at Sewanee, Cowan Station, distances between towns, and topographical features. Notes and the maps are presented in original order, which in general are reverse order from Alabama northward.

Major Francis Mohrhardt was a Union topographical engineer attached to Gen. Philip Sheridan's brigade of Rosecrans' Army of the Cumberland following the Battle of Stones River. His manuscript field notes, drawings and detailed maps of the 1863 Tullahoma Campaign are part of the Federal Collection of TSLA's Civil War Collection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A new map of Tennessee with its roads and distances from place to place along the stage and steamboat routes (1854)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map illustrates railroad and steamboat routes of Tennessee that were operating or being built in the 1850s. Lines and routes are named along with the land distances from town to town. Two insets show more detailed environs of Nashville and Knoxville.

This map helps convey the impact of the surge of railroad building that was taking place in the 1850s across the nation, and, specifically, in Tennessee. These early forays would give way to great railway systems that would improve transportation, aid the growth of the national economy, and play a key role in the Civil War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Battle of Saratoga: plan of the position taken by General Burgoyne on the 10th of October 1777
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of the Battle of Saratoga in which a British Army was invested by the Americans under the command of Gen. Gates and surrendered on Oct. 16, 1777. Saratoga was the first great American victory and a turning point in the colonies' struggle for independence, helping to bring France into the conflict on the American side.

The Battle of Saratoga marked the climax of the Saratoga campaign giving a decisive victory to the Americans over the British in the American Revolutionary War. British General John Burgoyne was surrounded by American forces in upstate New York where he fought two small battles that took place eighteen days apart near Saratoga, New York. Trapped by superior American forces, Burgoyne surrendered his entire army on October 17.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Civil War battlefields of Chattanooga
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One of a series of maps illustrating the campaigns in and around Chattanooga, this detailed topographical map shows the November 23-25, 1863 disposition of Union and Confederate forces at the Battle of Missionary Ridge, prepared under the direction of Daniel S. Lamont, Secretary of War and drawn by Edward E. Betts, Park Engineer. Shows Chattanooga and surrounding areas with stamps and markings showing troop locations and camps.

The Chattanooga and Chickamauga National Military Park was the first of the Civil War battlefields to be commemorated, and these maps were prepared by the Park Commission to map the military landscape that would be marked and interpreted in the park.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bird's-eye view of Nashville, Tenn. in the 1880s
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is an illustrated, hand tinted map of Nashville, (Tenn.) during the 1880s from an eastern perspective. Map has detailed and color-coded illustrations of Nashville commercial buildings, churches, houses, and structures from an aerial view. There is a numbered key at the bottom that provides names of businesses and buildings. The Cumberland River runs through the lower section of the map with steam boats passing along it. The city is in the center of the map and hills are in the distance in the upper section.

The original map was drawn and published originally by H. Wellge & Co., Milwaukee, in 1888. This is a facsimile of a print owned by Mr. Stanley F. Horn and reproduced with his kind permission in 1958 by First American National Bank of Nashville. It was tinted April 1969 by Katherine W. Ewing and presented to the Manuscript Division of the Tennessee State Library and Archives. A framed print of this map hangs in the Manuscripts area of the South Reading Room at TSLA.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Survey Map of Cherokee Country (ca. 1819), covering parts of eastern Tennessee and western North Carolina
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand drawn and colored maps of the Hiawassee region and Cherokee lands surveyed by Robert Armstrong, probably before the 1819 treaty opening for white settlement of these Cherokee lands of the so-called Hiawassee District. This map shows Cherokee villages (Cowee Town, Nanta[h]ala Town, Cittico Town, Tenawlly Town, Tallassee Town, Chilhowee Town, and Connasawga Town), named ferries, the Unicoy Turnpike and Federal Road,the "Great" and "Small" Tennessee Rivers, a portion of the Holston, Clinch and Tellico Rivers and portions of the current day Blue Ridge, Unicoi and Chilhowee mountains. Annotations on the maps include: "Supposed to contain two thousand souls great and small" and "Containing about sixteen hundred square miles between the Rivers Tenne[s]see Highwa[s]see N.C. Upwards of one million acres." One map is the more complete version, with a smaller, incomplete version on front and back.

Robert Armstrong (1774-1849) was the Knox County surveyor appointed by Secretary of War John C. Calhoun to be US Surveyor for the 1819 Cherokee Treaty, for which task these maps were produced. For more information on Armstrong and his work, see the register for the Grace Armstrong Coile Collection of Robert Armstrong Papers, 1790-1930.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Armstrong, Robert
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Colie, Grace Armstrong Collection of Robert Armstrong Papers 1790-1930

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Plan of New Orleans, the capital of Louisiana (1760)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawn from French sources (Mr. D'Anville) and published in London in 1760, this street plan of New Orleans shows the disposition of its streets, quarters and canals as they have been traced by Mr. de la Tour in the year 1720. Depicts what is now known as the Vieux Carre of the city, surrounded by open country. Shows block by block layout of New Orleans in 1720, showing street names, Ursuline convent, Place d'Armes, gardens, lots, , the King's Forge, brick kiln, powder magazine and vegetated areas. Right side shows parts of the Mississippi River ("River St. Louis, Called by the Natives Mississippi and Meshassepi"), one going into the Gulf of Mexico and the other with plans for Fort la Balise.

Jefferys, Thomas, -1771, known as "Geographer to King George III", was an English cartographer who was the leading map supplier of his day. He engraved and printed maps for government and produced a wide range of commercial maps and atlases, especially of North America. Map taken from between pages 148 and 149 of his volume on French Dominions in North and South America (1760).
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Brion de la Tour, Louis, 1743-1803

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: French dominions in North America from Mr. D'Anville (1760)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawn from French sources (Mr. D'Anville) and published in London in 1760, this map illustrates the colonial landscape of eastern North America and Canada at the time of the imperial struggle between France and England known as the Seven Year's War (French & Indian War). It is "Improved with the back settlements of Virginia and course of Ohio, illustrated with geographical and historical remarks." Map taken from between pages 134 and 135. Its chief value for Tennessee history lies in its depiction of the native Indian tribes, their settlements, colonial forts, rivers, etc. In the country of the "Cherakees" we find "Walkers Settlement 1750" on the "Cumberland or Shannoroens" River, the "Hogehege or Cherakees" [Tennessee] River, and many Cherokee towns, incl. "Tonase" which gave its name to the future state. In the country of the "Chikasaws" a "F[ort] Prudome [Prudhomme]" is shown near the future site of Memphis. The Creeks, "Chactaws" and other Southern tribes are shown.

Jefferys, Thomas, -1771, known as "Geographer to King George III", was an English cartographer who was the leading map supplier of his day. He engraved and printed maps for government and produced a wide range of commercial maps and atlases, especially of North America. Map taken from between pages 134 and 135 of his volume on French Dominions in North and South America (1760).
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Anville, Jean Baptiste Bourguignon d', 1697-1782

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the State of Tennessee taken from survey by Matthew Rhea (1832)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is the best overall map of Tennessee in the early national period. It shows counties, stage roads, Indian boundary lines, old forts, Indian villages, mills, iron works as well as streams, settlements, ranges and sections in West Tennessee, a geological cross-section of the state, a chronological statement of Tennessee history, a statistical table on counties showing dates established, and the total population and principal exports of counties. View of Nashville shown.
This map was published to accompany Eastin Morris' Tennessee Gazetteer in 1834.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Rhea, Matthew
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Eastin Morris' Tennessee gazetteer, 1834, F434.M87 1971 http://bit.ly/1vLhxwQ
